Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Situation2: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Story: The register beeped insistently as I counted the bills, my eyes scanning for errors. It was the end of my shift, and the drawer was full of large bills—one mistake, and I’d be in trouble. My phone buzzed in my pocket, and I glanced at the screen: it was my best friend, calling at 11:45 p.m. I hesitated, but the call came again, and this time I answered, whispering, “Hey, what’s wrong?” Her voice was shaky, words tumbling out between sobs about her family. I wanted to drop everything, to listen, to comfort her like I always did. But the line of customers was growing, and my manager was watching. My hands trembled as I tried to count the cash, my friend’s pain echoing in my ear. I felt torn—my friend needed me, but so did my job. The pressure built inside me, my heart racing as I tried to be present for her while not making a costly mistake. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing down, and I didn’t know which one to let down.
